docs.lead_paragraph: TO an outsider it looked like a reunion, which, in a way, it was. Friends greeted friends with hugs and with tears. ''I've missed you so much,'' someone said. ''It feels like years since I've seen you.'' Someone else walked over to the front plate-glass window and smoothed the edges of the American flag where the tape had sagged. Then the group filed into the empty party room to hear what their boss had to say. Tony May's business card says he is the owner of three restaurants, but the card is a month out of date. Mr. May owns but one restaurant now: San Domenico on Central Park South, where he has gathered his workers for this dinnertime meeting.
docs.abstract: Lisa Belkin column on reunion of World Trade Center restaurant workers; workers discuss fears stemming from terrorist attacks and job losses; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Gov. George E. Pataki and Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani announced an ambitious plan yesterday, asking the federal government to provide $54 billion worth of incentives, tax breaks and direct subsidies to rebuild New York State's economy, redevelop Lower Manhattan and help businesses hit hard by the World Trade Center attack. The plan includes tax exempt bonds for developers who want to build office space in the devastated zone, grants to persuade employers to keep their offices in Manhattan and a wish list of transportation projects around the state to stimulate the economy and create jobs.

headline.main: City and State Ask the U.S. For $54 Billion For Recovery
headline.kicker: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE FEDERAL AID

docs.abstract: Gov George E Pataki and Mayor Rudolph W Giuliani ask federal government to provide $54 billion worth of incentives, tax breaks and direct subsidies to rebuild New York State's economy, redevelop Lower Manhattan and help businesses hit hard by World Trade Center attack; plan includes tax exempt bonds for developers who build office space in devastated zone, grants to persuade employers to keep offices in Manhattan, and wish list of transportation projects around state to stimulate economy and create jobs; urge Pres Bush and federal lawmakers to recognize that rebuilding nation's financial capital is crucial to saving country's economy; representatives and senators from New York say it would be hard to persuade Republican leaders in Congress and others to approve many of measures governor and mayor are requesting; say size of package alone has some lawmakers worried; Sen Don Nickles, second-ranking Senate Republican, expresses skepticism about increasing aid to New York even before plan is announced; other big states around country are watching their economies and tax revenues sink, and Congress is worried about paying for war effort and antiterrorist measures; photo; chart with cost estimate for Sept 11 attack (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: One of Hasan Perez's two staff members, an Army reservist, has been placed on alert and may be called to active duty any day now. But, patriotic duty aside, Mr. Perez has been praying that she will not go. Mr. Perez worries about his employee, Christine Garcia-Figueroa, and her family. But he is equally anxious about the program he coordinates at the nonprofit Visiting Nurse Service of New York. His program finds housing for the homeless, but the fewer people he places, the less city money he receives.

headline.main: Contingency Plans to Fill Reservists' Shoes

docs.abstract: Employers are struggling to plug holes left by more than 27,025 National Guard and reservists called up for service in wake of terrorist attacks; managers are studying little-known law that protects soldiers' workplace rights; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-12 Pressed by Pakistan, India Rejects New Talks For the second time this week, President Pervez Musharraf of Pakistan invited Prime Minister Atal Behari Vajpayee of India to visit Islamabad for talks. A spokesman for the prime minister said the invitation had been declined, reflecting Indian anger about a terror attack by a Pakistan-based Islamic group on Oct. 1 in Kashmir that killed 38 people. A3 Arafat Fighting Dissension Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader, worked to contain his worst internal crisis in years by redirecting the anger at the cause that all factions could agree on: resisting Israel. docs.lead_paragraph: The state and two striking employee unions have agreed to resume mediation talks this week, a move prompted by attacks on Afghanistan, union officials said. The negotiations, scheduled for Thursday, would be the first since talks broke off more than a week ago, leading to the walkout of 23,000 state workers, or roughly half the state's work force. The walkout has slowed government services, including health inspections and vehicle licensing. The state has called on nearly 1,000 National Guard members to take over essential services like nursing care. The two sides remain at odds on pay and health insurance.

headline.main: National Briefing | Midwest: Minnesota: Talks To Resume

docs.abstract: Minnesota officials will resume talks with two striking employee unions (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: At the Beverly Hilton, 200 workers have lost their jobs and nearly 250 have been dismissed from the sparkling towers of the Westin Bonaventure. A Las Vegas casino company, Mandalay Resorts, will cut its work force by more than 4,000. The airline industry says 100,000 people will lose their jobs. Among hotel and restaurant workers, industry leaders say, the number of people with lost jobs or sharply reduced hours could reach a million.

headline.main: A Mass of Newly Laid-Off Workers Will Put Social Safety Net to the Test

docs.abstract: Layoffs that have followed September 11 terrorist attacks have shocked economy, and will pose significant new test of revamped social safety net; mass of newly unemployed workers will encounter welfare system that was overhauled in 1996 and has never faced recession, and has moved from federal control to patchwork of state programs that has, until now, been shielded by prosperity and low unemployment; photos (M)
